_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Aspire Bakeries has a long standing commitment to worker and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the Ammonia Refrigeration System.  Aspire Bakeries policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. 
The Aspire Bakeries facility is located at 15963 Strathern St, Van Nuys, California 91406.  The regulated substance managed at the facility is anhydrous ammonia and will report the estimated inventory of 11,081 pounds (lbs.) of anhydrous ammonia which has been rounded to 11,000 pounds per EPA RMP Guidance documents.  The maximum intended inventory for this facility is 11,720 pounds. Refer to the Process Safety Information section for related ammonia inventory calculations and information.
Although the storage and use of anhydrous ammonia has inherent potential risks, and worst-case release scenarios can potentially reach the community; Aspire Bakeries has recognized these potential risks and structured its safety programs to make the worst-case type of event non-credible.  In addition to the safety practices of the company and plant personnel to make this worst-case event non-credible, it should also be recognized that there are inherent analysis assumptions that make the results of the atmospheric dispersion analysis appear worse than what would actually be expected during such an event.
In addition to the use of conservative analysis assumptions that over-predict the effects of a potential release, other characteristics of the facility and site serve to minimize the potential risks associated with an ammonia release:
	Well-designed Relief System
	Safety Showers/Eyewash Stations
	Gas Detection (various locations, setpoints, and functions)
	Ammonia Diffusion Tank
As part of the implementation of this CalARP Program, key Prevention Program elements were docume

nted and implemented by Aspire to manage process safety issues associated with the use of ammonia.  Furthermore, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are currently utilized to ensure safe practices are being performed.
The facility maximum intended inventory of anhydrous ammonia exceeds 10,000 lbs.  As a result, the anhydrous ammonia covered process is subject to PSM Program Level 3 requirements.  The Prevention Program 3 elements include:
1.	Employee Participation
2.    Process Safety Information
3.	Process Hazard Analysis
4.	Operating Procedures
5.	Training
6.	Mechanical Integrity
7.	Compliance Audits
8.	Incident Investigation
9.    Management of Change
10.  Emergency Action Plan
11. Trade Secrets
13. Hot Work
14. Contractor Screening
For any accidental release meeting the five-year accident history reporting criteria of 19 CCR §2750.9, the owner or operator shall submit the data required under §2745.5, §2745.6, and §2745.7 with respect to that accident within six months of the release or by the time the RMP is updated under §2745.10, whichever is earlier.  19 CCR §2750.9 states:
The owner or operator shall include in the five-year accident history all accidental releases from covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.
The Aspire facility has had no releases in the last five years that meets the five-year accident history reporting criteria. 
Aspire Bakeries is a non-responding facility and does not train employees for active responses to ammonia releases.  This facility will rely upon the local emergency hazardous materials response team and the Los Angeles City Fire Department for responses to uncontrolled releases of anhydrous ammonia.  In accordance with 19 CCR §2765.1, the facility is not required to have an Emergency Response Plan in place.  However, it is required to have appropriate

mechanisms in place for notifying emergency responders when there is a need for response.  These mechanisms are described below.  
The facility has procedures in-place to evacuate the facility and notify responders when there is a need for a response.  A current copy of the Emergency Action Plan (EAP) can be found with the Bakery Director, and within the Emergency Planning and Response tab of the Compliance Workbook.  The EAP includes:
	Emergency Alarm Procedures
	Evacuation Procedures
	Safety and Health Considerations
	Notification Procedures
Pursuant to the requirements of California Code of Regulations, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, §2745.6(l); the following external events analysis information shall be submitted
	The types of natural and human caused external events considered in PHA Section 2760.2 or Hazard Review Section 2755.2.  
During the July 29 & 30, and September 17, 2024 PHA Revalidation, plausible events were considered an earthquake was identified as the most credible event.  General events external to the facility that can conceivably cause a release of ammonia were addressed. 
	The estimated magnitude or scope of external events which were considered. If not known, the owner or operator of the stationary source shall work closely with the AA to determine what is required. If seismic events are applicable, the parameters used in the consideration of the seismic analysis and which edition of the Uniform Building Code was used when the process was designed.
	The magnitudes of the external events considered are detailed within the PHA and were qualitatively risk-ranked by the PHA Team.
For each external event, with a potential to create a release of a regulated substance that will reach an endpoint offsite, apply the following (refer to Section 5.0 of this document, under PHA, for the required information).
o	The expected date of completion of any changes resulting from the PHA Revalidation;
o	Major hazards identified;
o	Process controls in
